content: The "United States Fire Administration Authorization Act for Fiscal Years 1998 and 1999" authorizes appropriations of $29,664,000 for the fiscal year ending September 30, 1998, and $30,554,000 for the fiscal year ending September 30, 1999. Additionally, successor fire safety standards are addressed. SEC. 3. SUCCESSOR FIRE SAFETY STANDARDS. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include successor standards for fire safety codes. The Administrator of the United States Fire Administration must notify Congress at least 60 days before terminating or transferring any significant function to a private entity. A termination or transfer is considered significant if it involves a function requiring more than 5% of the Administration's funds or the termination of more than 5% of its employees. SEC. 5. NOTICE. The term "major reorganization" for the United States Fire Administration involves reassigning over 25% of employees. Any reprogramming action requiring notice to Senate and House Committees must also inform the Committees on Commerce, Science, and Transportation. The Administrator must give a 15-day notice before any major reorganization of a program, project, or activity. The United States Fire Administration must notify specific House and Senate committees before any major reorganization involving over 25% of employees. Congress suggests donating such equipment to schools to enhance their science and mathematics programs. The Administrator must submit an annual report to the President detailing donations of educationally useful Federal equipment to schools. SEC. 8. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Administrator of the United States Fire Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The report will examine risks to firefighters from fires caused by burning tires, including exposure to toxic substances, personal protection, fire duration, and site hazards.
